fields.label: Does the business you want to register have a Unique Taxpayer Reference?
fields.shortName: Does the business have a UTR
fields.helpText: A Unique Taxpayer Reference is 10 numbers. It will be on tax returns and other letters from HMRC. It may be called ‘reference’, ‘UTR’ or ‘official use’.
fields.errorMessage: Select whether the business has a Unique Taxpayer Reference

sections.title: You can not register the business for this service

fields.infoText:
This is because the business must have a Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) to register for this service.

The business will automatically be sent a UTR when it:

* registers for Self Assessment

* sets up as a limited company

Information about [finding a lost UTR](https://www.gov.uk/find-lost-utr-number) can be found on GOV.UK

You'll need to exit this service.

fields.helpText: This is 10 numbers, for example 12345 67890. It will be on tax returns and other letters from HMRC. It may be called ‘reference’, ‘UTR’ or ‘official use’.

fields.label: Postcode of main place of business
fields.helpText: This should match the postcode HMRC holds for the business's Corporation Tax or Self Assessment details.

fields.infoText: You'll need to exit this service, check your records and come back and start again using the correct Unique Taxpayer Reference and postcode for the business you want to register.

fields.infoText: You must be authorised to act on behalf of the company to submit this registration. For example, a director or a company secretary (if you have one)

fields.label: Select the status relevant to you
fields.helpText: For limited companies, a director or company secretary must complete this declaration

fields.label: Email address
fields.helpText: We will send an email to this address to confirm the application has been submitted

fields.infoText: By submitting this application, you declare that the information that you have provided is true and complete.

You can avoid a financial penalty by applying for registration at the correct time. 

You have the right to appeal if we impose such a penalty.

HMRC will send you a letter to confirm your registration details and return date so you can prepare to submit your first Bingo Duty return.

You must contact your local authority to get a license to promote bingo events on all of your premises, even if you have started trading.
